t: “Even*pn today my complaint is bitter; his*ld hand is heavy in spite of my groaning.
If*ln only I knew where to find him; if*ld only I could go to his dwelling!
I*ln would state my case before him and*ld fill my mouth with arguments.
I*ln would find out what he would answer me, and*ld consider what he would say to me.
Would*ln he vigorously oppose me? No,*ld he would not press charges against me.
There*ln the upright can establish their innocence before him, and*ld there I would be delivered forever from my judge.
“But*pn if I go to the east, he is not there; if*ld I go to the west, I do not find him.
When*ln he is at work in the north, I do not see him; when*ld he turns to the south, I catch no glimpse of him.
But*ln he knows the way that I take; when*ld he has tested me, I will come forth as gold.
My*ln feet have closely followed his steps; I*ld have kept to his way without turning aside.
I*ln have not departed from the commands of his lips; I*ld have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread.
“But*pn he stands alone, and who can oppose him? He*ld does whatever he pleases.
He*ln carries out his decree against me, and*ld many such plans he still has in store.
That*ln is why I am terrified before him; when*ld I think of all this, I fear him.
God*ln has made my heart faint; the*ld Almighty has terrified me.
Yet*ln I am not silenced by the darkness, by*ld the thick darkness that covers my face.
